title: How to Make Three Ingredient Peanut Butter Cookies

steps.headline: Preheat the oven to 350 °F (177 °C) and line 2 sheets with parchment.
steps.description: Set the baking sheets aside and move the racks in the oven so 1 rack is in the upper third and 1 rack is in the lower third of the oven. If you don't have parchment paper, you can lay silicone baking mats on the sheets.

steps.headline: Whisk 1 egg with 1 cup (200 g) of sugar.
steps.description: Crack the egg into a mixing bowl and add the sugar of your choice. Whisk until the egg is completely combined with the sugar and the mixture looks light. Brown sugar will give the cookies a deeper flavor and chewier texture. White or powdered sugar will give the cookies a crispier texture and delicate flavor.

steps.headline: Stir in 1 cup (250 g) of creamy peanut butter.
steps.description: Add the peanut butter to the sugar and egg mixture. Stir until the mixture is combined and thick. You shouldn't be able to see pockets of sugar. If you use natural peanut butter, the dough may be runnier and the peanut butter flavor will be stronger.

steps.headline: Roll the dough into 1 in (2.5 cm) balls and put them on the sheets.
steps.description: Use a cookie scoop or spoons to portion the dough into small mounds. Roll each mound of dough between the palms of your hands to make 1 in (2.5 cm) balls. Then set them on the cookie sheet so they're 2 in (5 cm) apart. If you used natural peanut butter and the dough is too runny to shape, use a cookie scoop to drop tablespoonfuls of dough onto the baking sheets.

steps.headline: Press the tines of a fork down on each ball to make a crosshatch.
steps.description: Press a the fork down on a ball and then turn the tines 90 degrees. Press down again on the same ball to make a crosshatch pattern. Repeat this for every ball of dough. If you prefer, press down on the cookies with the decorative bottom of a glass or use a meat pounder. At this point, you can sprinkle the tops of the cookies with flaky salt or sugar for a little extra crunch.

steps.headline: Bake the cookies for 10 to 15 minutes.
steps.description: Put the baking sheets in the preheated oven and cook the peanut butter cookies until they're golden brown. Rotate the pans after 7 or 8 minutes to ensure the cookies bake evenly. The cookies should look dry around the edges, but the centers will still appear soft.

steps.headline: Cool the cookies on a wire rack.
steps.description: Remove the baking sheets from the oven and use a spatula to transfer the cookies to a wire rack. Let the cookies cool until they're warm and then enjoy! Store the leftover cooled cookies in an airtight container at room temperature for up to 3 days.

steps.headline: Preheat the oven to 350 °F (177 °C) and line a sheet with parchment.
steps.description: Get out 1 baking sheet and lay a sheet of parchment paper on it. If you don't have parchment paper, substitute a silicone baking mat. Avoid using waxed paper since you'll be baking the cookies and the wax would melt.

steps.headline: Put the peanut butter, sweetener, and ground chia seeds in a bowl.
steps.description:
Spoon 1 cup (250 g) of smooth peanut butter into a mixing bowl. Add 3/4 cup (150 g) of vegan sweetener and 3 tablespoons (42 g) of the ground chia seeds. For vegan sweeteners, consider using:
Raw cane sugar
Coconut palm or palm sugar
Beet sugar
Date sugar
Maple sugar
Stevia

steps.headline: Stir the ingredients to make a firm cookie dough.
steps.description: Use a spoon to mix the peanut butter, sweetener, and chia seeds until they're combined. If the cookie dough looks too thin to scoop, add the remaining 1 tablespoon (14 g) of ground chia seeds and stir them well. The chia seeds are a great egg replacer because they'll help bind the cookies together.

steps.headline: Scoop the dough into 1 in (2.5 cm) balls about 3 in (7.5 cm) apart.
steps.description: Use a cookie scoop or two spoons to shape the dough into 1 in (2.5 cm) mounds. Roll each mound of dough between your palms to make balls and set them on the baking sheet.

steps.headline: Use a fork to press down on the balls of dough.
steps.description: Push the fork tines down on each ball of dough. Then turn the fork 90 degrees and press down again so the ball of dough is about 2 to 3 in (5 to 7.5 cm) wide. If you don't want to use a fork, press down on the dough with the bottom of a decorative glass or use a meat pounder.

steps.headline: Bake the cookies for 8 to 10 minutes.
steps.description: Put the baking sheet in the preheated oven and bake the cookies until they're dry around the edges. They should be lightly golden in color once they've finished baking.

steps.headline: Cool the cookies and serve them.
steps.description: Transfer the cookies to a wire rack and let them cool until they're cool enough to handle. The cookies will be soft and chewy. Store leftover cookies in an airtight container for up to 1 week.

steps.headline: Line 2 baking sheets with parchment paper.
steps.description: Get out 2 rimmed baking sheets and line them with parchment paper. If you don't have parchment paper, substitute waxed paper. Set the sheets aside while you make the dough. The parchment or waxed paper will prevent the cookies from sticking to the sheet.

steps.headline: Heat the peanut butter and maple syrup over medium-low heat.
steps.description: Scoop 1 cup (250 g) of natural, unsalted creamy peanut butter into a small saucepan. Pour in ⁄2 cup (120 ml) of pure maple syrup and turn the burner to medium-low. Stir as the peanut butter melts into the maple syrup and begins to bubble a little. Then turn off the burner. Avoid heating the mixture over higher heat because the peanut butter can stick and burn.

steps.headline: Stir the oats and the peanut butter mixture to make a dough.
steps.description: Get out a bowl and put 2 cups (180 g) of rolled oats into it. Slowly pour the hot peanut butter maple syrup mixture over the oats and stir until the oats have absorbed a lot of the mixture.

steps.headline: Scoop the dough onto the baking sheets.
steps.description: Use a 2 tablespoon (30 ml) cookie scoop to spoon mounds of dough onto the parchment-lined baking sheets. Place each mound of dough about 2 in (5 cm) apart. Although you won't be baking these cookies, they'll need room to expand as you press on them.

steps.headline: Press down on the cookies with a fork or bottom of a glass.
steps.description: Push down on each mound of down with the tines of a fork. Turn the fork 90 degrees and press down again to make a crosshatched pattern. You can also make a simple design by pushing the bottom of a decorative glass on the dough. For thick cookies, don't press very hard. If you prefer thinner cookies, press until you almost reach the baking sheet.

steps.headline: Freeze the cookies for 15 to 25 minutes.
steps.description: Place the baking sheet into the freezer and chill the cookies until they're completely cold and set up. Remove the cookies and serve them cool or at room temperature. Refrigerate leftover cookies in an airtight container for the first day after you've made them. Then you can store them at room temperature for up to 1 month.

text:
Classic Peanut Butter Cookies Preheat the oven to 350 °F (177 °C) and line 2 sheets with parchment. Set the baking sheets aside and move the racks in the oven so 1 rack is in the upper third and 1 rack is in the lower third of the oven. If you don't have parchment paper, you can lay silicone baking mats on the sheets. Whisk 1 egg with 1 cup (200 g) of sugar. Crack the egg into a mixing bowl and add the sugar of your choice. Whisk until the egg is completely combined with the sugar and the mixture looks light. Brown sugar will give the cookies a deeper flavor and chewier texture. White or powdered sugar will give the cookies a crispier texture and delicate flavor. Stir in 1 cup (250 g) of creamy peanut butter. Add the peanut butter to the sugar and egg mixture. Stir until the mixture is combined and thick. You shouldn't be able to see pockets of sugar. If you use natural peanut butter, the dough may be runnier and the peanut butter flavor will be stronger. Roll the dough into 1 in (2.5 cm) balls and put them on the sheets. Use a cookie scoop or spoons to portion the dough into small mounds. Roll each mound of dough between the palms of your hands to make 1 in (2.5 cm) balls. Then set them on the cookie sheet so they're 2 in (5 cm) apart. If you used natural peanut butter and the dough is too runny to shape, use a cookie scoop to drop tablespoonfuls of dough onto the baking sheets. Press the tines of a fork down on each ball to make a crosshatch. Press a the fork down on a ball and then turn the tines 90 degrees. Press down again on the same ball to make a crosshatch pattern. Repeat this for every ball of dough. If you prefer, press down on the cookies with the decorative bottom of a glass or use a meat pounder. At this point, you can sprinkle the tops of the cookies with flaky salt or sugar for a little extra crunch. Bake the cookies for 10 to 15 minutes. Put the baking sheets in the preheated oven and cook the peanut butter cookies until they're golden brown. Rotate the pans after 7 or 8 minutes to ensure the cookies bake evenly. The cookies should look dry around the edges, but the centers will still appear soft. Cool the cookies on a wire rack. Remove the baking sheets from the oven and use a spatula to transfer the cookies to a wire rack. Let the cookies cool until they're warm and then enjoy! Store the leftover cooled cookies in an airtight container at room temperature for up to 3 days. Vegan Peanut Butter Cookies Preheat the oven to 350 °F (177 °C) and line a sheet with parchment. Get out 1 baking sheet and lay a sheet of parchment paper on it. If you don't have parchment paper, substitute a silicone baking mat. Avoid using waxed paper since you'll be baking the cookies and the wax would melt. Put the peanut butter, sweetener, and ground chia seeds in a bowl. Spoon 1 cup (250 g) of smooth peanut butter into a mixing bowl. Add 3/4 cup (150 g) of vegan sweetener and 3 tablespoons (42 g) of the ground chia seeds. For vegan sweeteners, consider using:
Raw cane sugar
Coconut palm or palm sugar
Beet sugar
Date sugar
Maple sugar
Stevia Stir the ingredients to make a firm cookie dough. Use a spoon to mix the peanut butter, sweetener, and chia seeds until they're combined. If the cookie dough looks too thin to scoop, add the remaining 1 tablespoon (14 g) of ground chia seeds and stir them well. The chia seeds are a great egg replacer because they'll help bind the cookies together. Scoop the dough into 1 in (2.5 cm) balls about 3 in (7.5 cm) apart. Use a cookie scoop or two spoons to shape the dough into 1 in (2.5 cm) mounds. Roll each mound of dough between your palms to make balls and set them on the baking sheet. Use a fork to press down on the balls of dough. Push the fork tines down on each ball of dough. Then turn the fork 90 degrees and press down again so the ball of dough is about 2 to 3 in (5 to 7.5 cm) wide. If you don't want to use a fork, press down on the dough with the bottom of a decorative glass or use a meat pounder. Bake the cookies for 8 to 10 minutes. Put the baking sheet in the preheated oven and bake the cookies until they're dry around the edges. They should be lightly golden in color once they've finished baking. Cool the cookies and serve them. Transfer the cookies to a wire rack and let them cool until they're cool enough to handle. The cookies will be soft and chewy. Store leftover cookies in an airtight container for up to 1 week. Peanut Butter Oatmeal Cookies Line 2 baking sheets with parchment paper. Get out 2 rimmed baking sheets and line them with parchment paper. If you don't have parchment paper, substitute waxed paper. Set the sheets aside while you make the dough. The parchment or waxed paper will prevent the cookies from sticking to the sheet. Heat the peanut butter and maple syrup over medium-low heat. Scoop 1 cup (250 g) of natural, unsalted creamy peanut butter into a small saucepan. Pour in ⁄2 cup (120 ml) of pure maple syrup and turn the burner to medium-low. Stir as the peanut butter melts into the maple syrup and begins to bubble a little. Then turn off the burner. Avoid heating the mixture over higher heat because the peanut butter can stick and burn. Stir the oats and the peanut butter mixture to make a dough. Get out a bowl and put 2 cups (180 g) of rolled oats into it. Slowly pour the hot peanut butter maple syrup mixture over the oats and stir until the oats have absorbed a lot of the mixture. Scoop the dough onto the baking sheets. Use a 2 tablespoon (30 ml) cookie scoop to spoon mounds of dough onto the parchment-lined baking sheets. Place each mound of dough about 2 in (5 cm) apart. Although you won't be baking these cookies, they'll need room to expand as you press on them. Press down on the cookies with a fork or bottom of a glass. Push down on each mound of down with the tines of a fork. Turn the fork 90 degrees and press down again to make a crosshatched pattern. You can also make a simple design by pushing the bottom of a decorative glass on the dough. For thick cookies, don't press very hard. If you prefer thinner cookies, press until you almost reach the baking sheet. Freeze the cookies for 15 to 25 minutes. Place the baking sheet into the freezer and chill the cookies until they're completely cold and set up. Remove the cookies and serve them cool or at room temperature. Refrigerate leftover cookies in an airtight container for the first day after you've made them. Then you can store them at room temperature for up to 1 month.
sentences: Classic Peanut Butter Cookies Preheat the oven to 350 °F (177 °C) and line 2 sheets with parchment.
Set the baking sheets aside and move the racks in the oven so 1 rack is in the upper third and 1 rack is in the lower third of the oven.
If you don't have parchment paper, you can lay silicone baking mats on the sheets.
Whisk 1 egg with 1 cup (200 g) of sugar.
Crack the egg into a mixing bowl and add the sugar of your choice.
Whisk until the egg is completely combined with the sugar and the mixture looks light.
Brown sugar will give the cookies a deeper flavor and chewier texture.
White or powdered sugar will give the cookies a crispier texture and delicate flavor.
Stir in 1 cup (250 g) of creamy peanut butter.
Add the peanut butter to the sugar and egg mixture.
Stir until the mixture is combined and thick.
You shouldn't be able to see pockets of sugar.
If you use natural peanut butter, the dough may be runnier and the peanut butter flavor will be stronger.
Roll the dough into 1 in (2.5 cm) balls and put them on the sheets.
Use a cookie scoop or spoons to portion the dough into small mounds.
Roll each mound of dough between the palms of your hands to make 1 in (2.5 cm) balls.
Then set them on the cookie sheet so they're 2 in (5 cm) apart.
If you used natural peanut butter and the dough is too runny to shape, use a cookie scoop to drop tablespoonfuls of dough onto the baking sheets.
Press the tines of a fork down on each ball to make a crosshatch.
Press a the fork down on a ball and then turn the tines 90 degrees.
Press down again on the same ball to make a crosshatch pattern.
Repeat this for every ball of dough.
If you prefer, press down on the cookies with the decorative bottom of a glass or use a meat pounder.
At this point, you can sprinkle the tops of the cookies with flaky salt or sugar for a little extra crunch.
Bake the cookies for 10 to 15 minutes.
Put the baking sheets in the preheated oven and cook the peanut butter cookies until they're golden brown.
Rotate the pans after 7 or 8 minutes to ensure the cookies bake evenly.
The cookies should look dry around the edges, but the centers will still appear soft.
Cool the cookies on a wire rack.
Remove the baking sheets from the oven and use a spatula to transfer the cookies to a wire rack.
Let the cookies cool until they're warm and then enjoy!
Store the leftover cooled cookies in an airtight container at room temperature for up to 3 days.
Vegan Peanut Butter Cookies Preheat the oven to 350 °F (177 °C) and line a sheet with parchment.
Get out 1 baking sheet and lay a sheet of parchment paper on it.
If you don't have parchment paper, substitute a silicone baking mat.
Avoid using waxed paper since you'll be baking the cookies and the wax would melt.
Put the peanut butter, sweetener, and ground chia seeds in a bowl.
Spoon 1 cup (250 g) of smooth peanut butter into a mixing bowl.
Add 3/4 cup (150 g) of vegan sweetener and 3 tablespoons (42 g) of the ground chia seeds.

For vegan sweeteners, consider using:
Raw cane sugar
Coconut palm or palm sugar
Beet sugar
Date sugar
Maple sugar
Stevia Stir the ingredients to make a firm cookie dough.
Use a spoon to mix the peanut butter, sweetener, and chia seeds until they're combined.
If the cookie dough looks too thin to scoop, add the remaining 1 tablespoon (14 g) of ground chia seeds and stir them well.
The chia seeds are a great egg replacer because they'll help bind the cookies together.
Scoop the dough into 1 in (2.5 cm) balls about 3 in (7.5 cm) apart.
Use a cookie scoop or two spoons to shape the dough into 1 in (2.5 cm) mounds.
Roll each mound of dough between your palms to make balls and set them on the baking sheet.
Use a fork to press down on the balls of dough.
Push the fork tines down on each ball of dough.
Then turn the fork 90 degrees and press down again so the ball of dough is about 2 to 3 in (5 to 7.5 cm) wide.
If you don't want to use a fork, press down on the dough with the bottom of a decorative glass or use a meat pounder.
Bake the cookies for 8 to 10 minutes.
Put the baking sheet in the preheated oven and bake the cookies until they're dry around the edges.
They should be lightly golden in color once they've finished baking.
Cool the cookies and serve them.
Transfer the cookies to a wire rack and let them cool until they're cool enough to handle.
The cookies will be soft and chewy.
Store leftover cookies in an airtight container for up to 1 week.
Peanut Butter Oatmeal Cookies Line 2 baking sheets with parchment paper.
Get out 2 rimmed baking sheets and line them with parchment paper.
If you don't have parchment paper, substitute waxed paper.
Set the sheets aside while you make the dough.
The parchment or waxed paper will prevent the cookies from sticking to the sheet.
Heat the peanut butter and maple syrup over medium-low heat.
Scoop 1 cup (250 g) of natural, unsalted creamy peanut butter into a small saucepan.
Pour in ⁄2 cup (120 ml) of pure maple syrup and turn the burner to medium-low.
Stir as the peanut butter melts into the maple syrup and begins to bubble a little.
Then turn off the burner.
Avoid heating the mixture over higher heat because the peanut butter can stick and burn.
Stir the oats and the peanut butter mixture to make a dough.
Get out a bowl and put 2 cups (180 g) of rolled oats into it.
Slowly pour the hot peanut butter maple syrup mixture over the oats and stir until the oats have absorbed a lot of the mixture.
Scoop the dough onto the baking sheets.
Use a 2 tablespoon (30 ml) cookie scoop to spoon mounds of dough onto the parchment-lined baking sheets.
Place each mound of dough about 2 in (5 cm) apart.
Although you won't be baking these cookies, they'll need room to expand as you press on them.
Press down on the cookies with a fork or bottom of a glass.
Push down on each mound of down with the tines of a fork.
Turn the fork 90 degrees and press down again to make a crosshatched pattern.
You can also make a simple design by pushing the bottom of a decorative glass on the dough.
For thick cookies, don't press very hard.
If you prefer thinner cookies, press until you almost reach the baking sheet.
Freeze the cookies for 15 to 25 minutes.
Place the baking sheet into the freezer and chill the cookies until they're completely cold and set up.
Remove the cookies and serve them cool or at room temperature.
Refrigerate leftover cookies in an airtight container for the first day after you've made them.
Then you can store them at room temperature for up to 1 month.
